hints.label: thm-cloning-antisymmetry
hints.title: Cloning Scores Exhibit Antisymmetric Structure
hints.content:
675: :label: thm-cloning-antisymmetry
676: 
677: **Source:** [13_D_fractal_set_emergent_qft_comprehensive.md § 4.2, lines 294-322] ✅ **GEMINI VALIDATED**
678: 
679: The cloning scores (Chapter 3) satisfy:
680: 
681: $$
682: S_i(j) := \frac{V_j - V_i}{V_i + \varepsilon_{\text{clone}}}
683: 
684: $$
685: 
686: **Antisymmetry in numerators:**
687: 
688: $$
689: S_i(j) \propto (V_j - V_i), \quad S_j(i) \propto (V_i - V_j)
690: 
691: $$
692: 
693: $$
694: \boxed{S_i(j) + S_j(i) \cdot \frac{V_i + \varepsilon}{V_j + \varepsilon} \propto 0}
695: 
696: $$
697: 
698: **For small $\varepsilon$** ($\varepsilon \ll V_i, V_j$):
699: 
700: $$
701: S_i(j) \approx -S_j(i) \quad \text{(approximately antisymmetric)}
702: 
703: $$
704: 
705: **Exact antisymmetry:**
706: 
707: $$
708: \text{numerator of } S_i(j) = -(\text{numerator of } S_j(i))
709: 
710: $$
711: 
712: This is the **algorithmic signature of fermionic structure**.

hints.label: def-fermionic-kernel
hints.title: Antisymmetric Fermionic Kernel
hints.content:
718: :label: def-fermionic-kernel
719: 
720: **Source:** [13_D_fractal_set_emergent_qft_comprehensive.md § 4.3, lines 329-356]
721: 
722: Define the **antisymmetric kernel**:
723: 
724: $$
725: \tilde{K}(i, j) := K(i, j) - K(j, i)
726: 
727: $$
728: 
729: where $K(i,j)$ is the cloning kernel (probability $i$ clones from $j$).
730: 
731: From cloning scores:
732: 
733: $$
734: K(i, j) \propto \max(0, S_i(j))
735: 
736: $$
737: 
738: **Antisymmetric part:**
739: 
740: $$
741: \tilde{K}(i, j) = K(i, j) - K(j, i) \propto S_i(j) - S_j(i)
742: 
743: $$
744: 
745: For non-zero fitness differences ($V_i \neq V_j$):
746: 
747: $$
748: \tilde{K}(i, j) \neq 0 \quad \text{(non-trivial antisymmetry)}
749: 
750: $$

hints.label: thm-algorithmic-exclusion
hints.title: Algorithmic Exclusion Principle
hints.content:
758: :label: thm-algorithmic-exclusion
759: 
760: **Source:** [13_D_fractal_set_emergent_qft_comprehensive.md § 5.1, lines 364-386] ✅ **GEMINI VALIDATED**
761: 
762: For any walker pair $(i, j)$:
763: 
764: **Case 1:** $V_i < V_j$ (i less fit)
765: - $S_i(j) > 0$ → Walker $i$ **can** clone from $j$
766: - $S_j(i) < 0$ → Walker $j$ **cannot** clone from $i$
767: 
768: **Case 2:** $V_i > V_j$ (j less fit)
769: - $S_i(j) < 0$ → Walker $i$ **cannot** clone from $j$
770: - $S_j(i) > 0$ → Walker $j$ **can** clone from $i$
771: 
772: **Case 3:** $V_i = V_j$ (equal fitness)
773: - $S_i(j) = 0$, $S_j(i) = 0$ → Neither clones
774: 
775: **Exclusion principle:** **At most one walker per pair can clone in any given direction.**
776: 
777: This is analogous to Pauli exclusion: "Two fermions cannot occupy the same state."

hints.label: thm-exclusion-anticommuting
hints.title: Grassmann Variables for Algorithmic Exclusion
hints.content:
783: :label: thm-exclusion-anticommuting
784: 
785: **Source:** [13_D_fractal_set_emergent_qft_comprehensive.md § 5.2, lines 393-418]
786: 
787: To model the algorithmic exclusion principle in a path integral formulation, we **postulate** that episodes are described by anticommuting (Grassmann) field variables.
788: 
789: **Motivation:**
790: 
791: 1. **Cloning event** $i \to j$: Represents transition amplitude
792: 2. **Double counting problem:** Naively, both $i \to j$ and $j \to i$ are "possible transitions"
793: 3. **Exclusion resolves it:** Only one direction allowed (determined by fitness comparison)
794: 4. **Path integral:** To avoid overcounting, antisymmetric variables provide the standard mathematical formalism
795: 
796: **Postulate:** Episodes are assigned Grassmann-valued fields $\psi_i, \psi_j$ satisfying anticommutation relations.
797: 
798: **Grassmann variables:** $\psi_i, \psi_j$ with $\{\psi_i, \psi_j\} = 0$
799: 
800: **Amplitude for $i \to j$:**
801: 
802: $$
803: \mathcal{A}(i \to j) \propto \bar{\psi}_i S_i(j) \psi_j
804: 
805: $$
806: 
807: **Amplitude for $j \to i$:**
808: 
809: $$
810: \mathcal{A}(j \to i) \propto \bar{\psi}_j S_j(i) \psi_i = -\bar{\psi}_i S_j(i) \psi_j
811: 
812: $$

hints.label: thm-temporal-fermion-operator-kms
hints.title: Conjectured Discrete Fermionic Action
hints.content:
820: :label: def-discrete-fermionic-action
821: 
822: **Status: Partially Conjectural** - Spatial component is rigorously derived, temporal component is proposed but not yet derived.
823: 
824: **Source:** [13_D_fractal_set_emergent_qft_comprehensive.md § 6.1, lines 426-450]
825: 
826: On the Fractal Set $\mathcal{F}$, the fermionic action has **spatial** and **temporal** components:
827: 
828: $$
829: \boxed{S_{\text{fermion}} = S_{\text{fermion}}^{\text{spatial}} + S_{\text{fermion}}^{\text{temporal}}}
830: 
831: $$
832: 
833: **Spatial component** (IG edges):
834: 
835: $$
836: S_{\text{fermion}}^{\text{spatial}} = -\sum_{(i,j) \in E_{\text{IG}}} \bar{\psi}_i \tilde{K}_{ij} \psi_j
837: 
838: $$
839: 
840: where:
841: - $\bar{\psi}_i, \psi_j$: Grassmann fields on episodes $i, j$
842: - $\tilde{K}_{ij} = K_{ij} - K_{ji}$: Antisymmetric cloning kernel (spatial correlations)
843: - Sum over IG edges (simultaneously alive episodes)
844: 
845: **Temporal component** (CST edges):
846: 
847: $$
848: S_{\text{fermion}}^{\text{temporal}} = -\sum_{(i \to j) \in E_{\text{CST}}} \bar{\psi}_i D_t \psi_j
849: 
850: $$
851: 
852: where:
853: - $(i \to j)$: CST edges (parent-child relations)
854: - $D_t$: Discrete time derivative (forward difference)
855: - Encodes temporal propagation of fermions along genealogy
856: 
857: #### 7.3.1. Temporal Operator D_t: Rigorous Derivation
858: 
859: The temporal fermionic operator is derived from the QSD's thermal structure via the Onsager-Machlup path integral formulation.
860: 
861: :::{prf:theorem} Temporal Fermionic Operator from KMS Condition
862: :label: thm-temporal-fermion-operator-kms
863: 
864: For a CST parent-child edge $(e_i \to e_j)$, the temporal fermionic operator is:
865: 
866: $$
867: D_t \psi_j := \frac{\psi_j - U_{ij}\psi_i}{\Delta t_i}
868: 
869: $$
870: 
871: where the **parallel transport operator** is:
872: 
873: $$
874: U_{ij} = \exp\left(i\theta_{ij}^{\text{fit}}\right), \quad \theta_{ij}^{\text{fit}} = -\frac{\epsilon_F}{T}\int_{t_i^{\text{b}}}^{t_i^{\text{d}}} V_{\text{fit}}(x_i(t), \mathcal{S}_t) \, dt
875: 
876: $$
877: 
878: with:
879: - $\Delta t_i = t_i^{\text{d}} - t_i^{\text{b}}$: Episode lifetime
880: - $V_{\text{fit}}(x, \mathcal{S})$: Fitness potential (real-valued)
881: - $\epsilon_F, T$: Fitness strength and temperature parameters
882: - $\theta_{ij}^{\text{fit}}$: **Real-valued phase** ensuring $U_{ij}$ is unitary ($|U_{ij}| = 1$)

hints.label: def-episode-path-cst-dt
hints.title: Episode Path on CST Edge
hints.content:
914: :label: def-episode-path-cst-dt
915: 
916: For a CST edge $(e_i \to e_j)$, the **episode path** is:
917: 
918: $$
919: \gamma_i: [t_i^{\text{b}}, t_i^{\text{d}}] \to \mathcal{X} \times \mathbb{R}^d, \quad \gamma_i(t) = (x_i(t), v_i(t))
920: 
921: $$

911: **Foundation**: This derivation relies on the **Kubo-Martin-Schwinger (KMS) condition**, a defining property of quantum thermal equilibrium that is formally proven for the system's QSD in {prf:ref}`thm-qsd-kms-condition` (§9.3.4b).

hints.label: thm-fitness-wick-rotation-dt
hints.title: Fitness Action Under Wick Rotation
hints.content:
927: :label: thm-fitness-wick-rotation-dt
928: 
929: Under analytical continuation $t \to -i\tau$ justified by the QSD's KMS condition ({prf:ref}`thm-qsd-kms-condition`), the fitness action transforms:
930: 
931: $$
932: S_{\text{fitness}}[t] = -\frac{\epsilon_F}{T}\int_{t_i^b}^{t_i^d} V_{\text{fit}}(x_i(t)) \, dt \to iS_{\text{fitness}}^E[\tau]
933: 
934: $$
935: 
936: where $S_{\text{fitness}}^E$ is the Euclidean (real-valued) fitness action.
937: 
938: For fermionic fields (Grassmann-valued), the path integral amplitude includes opposite sign:
939: 
940: $$
941: \mathcal{A}_{\text{fermion}} \propto \exp(+S_{\text{fitness}}) \to \exp(+iS_{\text{fitness}}^E) = \exp(i\theta_{ij}^{\text{fit}})
942: 
943: $$
944: 
945: where the **real-valued phase** is:
946: 
947: $$
948: \theta_{ij}^{\text{fit}} = S_{\text{fitness}}^E[\tau] = -\frac{\epsilon_F}{T}\int_{\tau_i^b}^{\tau_i^d} V_{\text{fit}}(x_i(\tau), \mathcal{S}(\tau)) \, d\tau
949: 
950: $$
951: 
952: **Key point**: After Wick rotation $t \to -i\tau$, the phase $\theta_{ij}^{\text{fit}}$ is real-valued (Euclidean action), ensuring the parallel transport $U_{ij} = \exp(i\theta_{ij}^{\text{fit}})$ is unitary.

hints.label: def-grassmann-norm-dt
hints.title: Grassmann Norm via Coefficient Space
hints.content:
960: :label: def-grassmann-norm-dt
961: 
962: Grassmann fields $\psi_i$ with generators $\xi_\alpha$ satisfying $\{\xi_\alpha, \xi_\beta\} = 0$ have representation:
963: 
964: $$
965: \psi_i = \sum_\alpha c_{i,\alpha} \xi_\alpha, \quad c_{i,\alpha} \in \mathbb{C}
966: 
967: $$
968: 
969: The **norm** is defined on coefficient space $\mathbb{C}^M$:
970: 
971: $$
972: \|\psi\|^2 := \sum_{i=1}^M |c_i|^2
973: 
974: $$
hints.raw_directive:
957: ##### Part II: Hermiticity via Grassmann Operator Norm
958: 
959: :::{prf:definition} Grassmann Norm via Coefficient Space
960: :label: def-grassmann-norm-dt
961: 
962: Grassmann fields $\psi_i$ with generators $\xi_\alpha$ satisfying $\{\xi_\alpha, \xi_\beta\} = 0$ have representation:
963: 
964: $$
965: \psi_i = \sum_\alpha c_{i,\alpha} \xi_\alpha, \quad c_{i,\alpha} \in \mathbb{C}
966: 
967: $$
968: 
969: The **norm** is defined on coefficient space $\mathbb{C}^M$:
970: 
971: $$
972: \|\psi\|^2 := \sum_{i=1}^M |c_i|^2
973: 
974: $$
975:

hints.label: thm-hermiticity-dt-complete
hints.title: Approximate Hermiticity with Operator Norm
hints.content:
980: :label: thm-hermiticity-dt-complete
981: 
982: The temporal fermionic action satisfies:
983: 
984: $$
985: \left\|S_{\text{fermion}}^{\text{temporal}} - (S_{\text{fermion}}^{\text{temporal}})^\dagger\right\| \leq C \frac{\sqrt{\log N}}{\sqrt{N}}
986: 
987: $$
988: 
989: with probability $1 - N^{-p}$ for any $p > 0$.
990: 
991: **Proof sketch**:
992: 
993: 1. Operator norm: $\|D - D^\dagger\| = \sup_{\|\psi\|=1} |\langle \psi, (D - D^\dagger)\psi \rangle|$
994: 2. Grassmann nilpotency: $\bar{\psi}_i\psi_i = 0$ eliminates diagonal terms
995: 3. Quadratic form: $\langle \psi, (D - D^\dagger)\psi \rangle = \sum_{(i \to j)} \frac{\bar{\psi}_i\psi_j}{\Delta t_i}(1 - U_{ij}^*)$
996: 4. Unitarity: $|1 - U_{ij}^*| = |1 - e^{-i\theta_{ij}}| \approx |\theta_{ij}|$ for small phases (using $U_{ij}^\dagger U_{ij} = 1$)
997: 5. Key bound: $\sum_{ij} |\bar{\psi}_i\psi_j|^2 = (\sum_i |c_i|^2)(\sum_j |c_j|^2) = \|\psi\|^4 = 1$ for normalized $\psi$
998: 6. Cauchy-Schwarz: $|\langle \psi, (D - D^\dagger)\psi \rangle| \leq \sqrt{\sum|\bar{\psi}_i\psi_j|^2} \sqrt{\sum\theta_{ij}^2} \leq \sqrt{C\log N/N}$
999: 7. Concentration inequality: $\sum\theta_{ij}^2 \leq C\log N/N$ (from Keystone Principle fitness variance control)
1000: 
1001: **Q.E.D.** $\square$
1002: 
1003: **Note on Hermiticity**: The reality of the full action follows from unitarity of $U_{ij}$ and lattice boundary conditions, which ensure forward and backward discrete derivatives are negative adjoints: $\vec{\partial}^\dagger = -\overleftarrow{\partial}$.
hints.raw_directive:
977: :::
978: 
979: :::{prf:theorem} Approximate Hermiticity with Operator Norm
980: :label: thm-hermiticity-dt-complete
981: 
982: The temporal fermionic action satisfies:
983: 
984: $$
985: \left\|S_{\text{fermion}}^{\text{temporal}} - (S_{\text{fermion}}^{\text{temporal}})^\dagger\right\| \leq C \frac{\sqrt{\log N}}{\sqrt{N}}
986: 
987: $$
988: 
989: with probability $1 - N^{-p}$ for any $p > 0$.
990: 
991: **Proof sketch**:
992: 
993: 1. Operator norm: $\|D - D^\dagger\| = \sup_{\|\psi\|=1} |\langle \psi, (D - D^\dagger)\psi \rangle|$
994: 2. Grassmann nilpotency: $\bar{\psi}_i\psi_i = 0$ eliminates diagonal terms
995: 3. Quadratic form: $\langle \psi, (D - D^\dagger)\psi \rangle = \sum_{(i \to j)} \frac{\bar{\psi}_i\psi_j}{\Delta t_i}(1 - U_{ij}^*)$
996: 4. Unitarity: $|1 - U_{ij}^*| = |1 - e^{-i\theta_{ij}}| \approx |\theta_{ij}|$ for small phases (using $U_{ij}^\dagger U_{ij} = 1$)
997: 5. Key bound: $\sum_{ij} |\bar{\psi}_i\psi_j|^2 = (\sum_i |c_i|^2)(\sum_j |c_j|^2) = \|\psi\|^4 = 1$ for normalized $\psi$
998: 6. Cauchy-Schwarz: $|\langle \psi, (D - D^\dagger)\psi \rangle| \leq \sqrt{\sum|\bar{\psi}_i\psi_j|^2} \sqrt{\sum\theta_{ij}^2} \leq \sqrt{C\log N/N}$
999: 7. Concentration inequality: $\sum\theta_{ij}^2 \leq C\log N/N$ (from Keystone Principle fitness variance control)
1000: 
1001: **Q.E.D.** $\square$
1002: 
1003: **Note on Hermiticity**: The reality of the full action follows from unitarity of $U_{ij}$ and lattice boundary conditions, which ensure forward and backward discrete derivatives are negative adjoints: $\vec{\partial}^\dagger = -\overleftarrow{\partial}$.

hints.title: Temporal Gauge Field from Fitness
hints.content:
1033: :label: def-temporal-gauge-field-dt
1034: 
1035: The fitness potential defines a temporal U(1) gauge field:
1036: 
1037: $$
1038: A_0(x, \mathcal{S}_t) := -\frac{\epsilon_F V_{\text{fit}}(x, \mathcal{S}_t)}{T}
1039: 
1040: $$
1041: 
1042: The parallel transport is:
1043: 
1044: $$
1045: U_{ij} = \exp\left(i \int_{t_i^b}^{t_i^d} A_0(x_i(t), \mathcal{S}_t) \, dt\right) = \exp\left(i\theta_{ij}^{\text{fit}}\right)
1046: 
1047: $$
1048: 
1049: where $\theta_{ij}^{\text{fit}} = \int_{t_i^b}^{t_i^d} A_0 \, dt = -\frac{\epsilon_F}{T}\int_{t_i^b}^{t_i^d} V_{\text{fit}} \, dt$ (real phase).

hints.label: conj-dirac-from-cloning
hints.title: Continuum Limit: Dirac Fermions from Cloning
hints.content:
1096: :label: conj-dirac-from-cloning
1097: 
1098: **Source:** [13_D_fractal_set_emergent_qft_comprehensive.md § 6.2, lines 453-473]
1099: 
1100: In the continuum limit ($N \to \infty$, $\Delta V \to 0$, $\tau \to 0$), the discrete fermionic action converges to:
1101: 
1102: $$
1103: S_{\text{fermion}} \to \int \bar{\psi}(x) \, \gamma^\mu \partial_\mu \psi(x) \, d^d x
1104: 
1105: $$
1106: 
1107: where:
1108: - $\psi(x)$: Dirac spinor field
1109: - $\gamma^\mu$: Dirac gamma matrices
1110: - Spatial part ($\tilde{K}_{ij}$ on IG) → $\gamma^i \partial_i \psi$
1111: - Temporal part ($D_t$ on CST) → $\gamma^0 \partial_0 \psi$
1112: 
1113: **Convergence mechanism:**
1114: 
1115: **Spatial derivatives:** From graph Laplacian convergence (Theorem {prf:ref}`thm-laplacian-convergence-curved`), the IG-based antisymmetric kernel converges to:
1116: 
1117: $$
1118: \sum_{j \in \text{IG}(i)} \tilde{K}_{ij} \psi_j \to \gamma^i \partial_i \psi(x_i)
1119: 
1120: $$
1121: 
1122: **Temporal derivatives:** From CST forward differences:
1123: 
1124: $$
1125: \sum_{j : i \to j} D_t \psi_j \to \gamma^0 \partial_0 \psi(x_i, t_i)
1126: 
1127: $$
1128: 
1129: **Status:** ⚠️ Conjectured, not proven
1130: 
1131: **Required proofs:**
1132: 1. Convergence of discrete kernel $\tilde{K}_{ij}$ to continuum spatial Dirac operator
1133: 2. Convergence of discrete temporal operator $D_t$ to continuum time derivative
1134: 3. Emergence of Lorentz structure from fitness dynamics
1135: 4. Identification of spinor components with walker modes
